text: May 7 / Administration of William J. Clinton, 1999
label: BODY

text: Barbara Jordan’s incomparable voice for jus-
label: BODY

text: tice on common ground.
label: BODY

text: Since I’m here today, I cannot help noting
label: BODY

text: that the work of Lyndon Johnson and Bar-
label: BODY

text: bara Jordan is being carried on today here
label: BODY

text: in Austin by the State legislators who are try-
label: BODY

text: ing to pass hate crimes legislation in the
label: BODY

text: name of James Byrd. As you probably saw
label: BODY

text: on the tarmac, I was honored to meet with
label: BODY

text: members of Mr. Byrd’s family. I know that
label: BODY

text: what happened to him was anathema to every
label: BODY

text: good citizen in Texas, as well as the United
label: BODY

text: States.
label: BODY

text: And I ask you, as our men and women
label: BODY

text: in uniform today struggle against the killing,
label: BODY

text: the rape, the looting, the uprooting of peo-
label: BODY

text: ple, based solely on their ethnic and religious
label: BODY

text: background in Kosovo, as they did in Bosnia,
label: BODY

text: as we fight to reconcile people around the
label: BODY

text: world, from the Middle East to Northern Ire-
label: BODY

text: land, here in America, if we want to do good
label: BODY

text: abroad, we have to be good at home. We
label: BODY

text: have to stand up for what is right.
label: BODY

text: We have to acknowledge that there are dif-
label: BODY

text: ferences among us that we celebrate. There
label: BODY

text: are differences among us that are real dif-
label: BODY

text: ferences, and we are compelled to disagree.
label: BODY

text: But underneath it all, as the Founders of our
label: BODY

text: Republic recognized, there is our common
label: BODY

text: humanity and our equal dignity. And we
label: BODY

text: must always stand for it. If we want to be
label: BODY

text: a force against ethnic cleansing and genocide
label: BODY

text: around the world, we have to be a force for
label: BODY

text: harmony and community, here at home in
label: BODY

text: every place in the United States.
label: BODY

text: And so I close with the point I tried to
label: BODY

text: make at the beginning. I want you to think
label: BODY

text: about what this represents and how you did
label: BODY

text: it. What it represents is a commitment to a
label: BODY

text: common future, where no one is left behind
label: BODY

text: and everybody has a chance. How you did
label: BODY

text: it is by working together, across all the ele-
label: BODY

text: ments of this richly textured community. If
label: BODY

text: you think about it, we could solve all of our
label: BODY

text: problems that way. Thanks for the model.
label: BODY

text: Good luck, and God bless you.
label: BODY

text: Wait a minute. I want to do one other
label: BODY

text: thing. I want to thank the Barbara Jordan
label: BODY

text: Elementary Choir and the Pflugerville High
label: BODY

text: School Band. Thank you very much. How
label: BODY

text: about a little more music? Let’s go.
label: BODY

text: NOTE: The President spoke at 5:38 p.m. In his
label: BODY

text: remarks, he referred to Mayor Kirk Watson of
label: BODY

text: Austin, TX; and former Representative J.J. Pickle.
label: BODY

text: This item was not received in time for publication
label: BODY

text: in the appropriate issue.
label: BODY

text: Remarks at a Democratic National
label: HH1

text: Committee Dinner in Austin
label: BODY

text: Thank you very much. You know, when
label: BODY

text: Roy was doing that riff, you know, ‘‘Before
label: BODY

text: he came, I didn’t know I needed new fur-
label: BODY

text: niture; I didn’t know I needed new art work;
label: BODY

text: I didn’t know I needed’’—Mary kept getting
label: BODY

text: redder and redder, and finally she says, ‘‘He
label: BODY

text: may not know he needs another place to
label: BODY

text: spend the night tonight.’’ [Laughter] I must
label: BODY

text: say this is a lot better than the last hovel
label: BODY

text: we spent the night in. [Laughter]
label: BODY

text: Let me say to all of you, I’ve had a wonder-
label: BODY

text: ful time here tonight, seeing so many of my
label: BODY

text: old friends. There are a lot of people here—
label: BODY

text: the ones Roy mentioned and also Carlos
label: BODY

text: Truan, Gonzalo Barrientos—a lot of other
label: BODY

text: people who were with Roy and Gary and
label: BODY

text: Judy and Nancy and Tom, all the rest of us,
label: BODY

text: way back in 1972. And we have remained
label: BODY

text: friends for a long time. And during most of
label: BODY

text: that time, with the odd interruption, some-
label: BODY

text: times the odd, wonderful interruption like
label: BODY

text: the reign of Governor Richards, the election
label: BODY

text: of Lloyd Doggett, we’ve been in the minor-
label: BODY

text: ity.
label: BODY

text: And I want to talk tonight a little bit
label: BODY

text: about—I want to have kind of a serious con-
label: BODY

text: versation tonight about why I really came
label: BODY

text: here, because what Joe said is right. I’m not
label: BODY

text: running for anything. And I would seize any
label: BODY

text: excuse to come here to Austin, because I had
label: BODY

text: some of the happiest days of my life here,
label: BODY

text: and I have a very jealous wife who wishes
label: BODY

text: she were here today.
label: BODY

text: But for the next 2 years, I’m helping the
label: BODY

text: Democratic Party because I believe it’s the
label: BODY

text: right thing to do for America. I hear a lot
label: BODY

text: of folks on the other side kind of licking their
label: BODY

text: lips and saying, ‘‘Well, wait until the next
label: BODY

text: election, and we’ll have Clinton out of the
label: BODY

text: way. Maybe it will be better.’’
label: BODY

text: What I want to say to you is that I am
label: BODY

text: very grateful that I’ve had the chance to serve
label: BODY

text: you. And I am profoundly grateful that we
label: BODY

text: Administration of William J. Clinton, 1999 / May 7
label: BODY

text: have the lowest unemployment in 30 years
label: BODY

text: and the lowest welfare rolls in forever and
label: BODY

text: a day—they’re half the size they were be-
label: BODY

text: fore—and the lowest crime rate in 25 years.
label: BODY

text: Roy was saying that we’ve got 90 percent of
label: BODY

text: our children immunized against serious dis-
label: BODY

text: eases for the first time in history. The doors
label: BODY

text: of college are virtually open to every Amer-
label: BODY

text: ican now because of our HOPE tax credit
label: BODY

text: and the student loan changes we’ve made.
label: BODY

text: We’ve set aside more land in perpetuity than
label: BODY

text: any administration, except for the two Roo-
label: BODY

text: sevelts, in American history. I’m grateful for
label: BODY

text: all that.
label: BODY

text: But what I want you to understand is that
label: BODY

text: I’m grateful because I got a chance to imple-
label: BODY

text: ment a set of ideas that now represent the
label: BODY

text: governing philosophy of the Democratic
label: BODY

text: Party. And it is very different from the driv-
label: BODY

text: ing philosophy of the other party. And if the
label: BODY

text: American people like the results that have
label: BODY

text: been achieved, then we need to support
label: BODY

text: those people running for the Congress and
label: BODY

text: the White House who believe in these ideas.
label: BODY

text: In 1991, when the incumbent President
label: BODY

text: was at 75 percent approval and I decided to
label: BODY

text: make this race when nobody but my mother
label: BODY

text: and my wife thought I could win, I did it
label: BODY

text: because I was worried about my country and
label: BODY

text: my Capital. Because it seemed to me that
label: BODY

text: there was nothing particularly wrong with
label: BODY

text: America that couldn’t be fixed if we would
label: BODY

text: just open our eyes and go to work. The un-
label: BODY

text: employment rate was high, inequality was in-
label: BODY

text: creasing, the social problems were worsen-
label: BODY

text: ing, and we had a lot of problems around
label: BODY

text: the world that we didn’t seem to have any
label: BODY

text: governing idea of dealing with. But I felt
label: BODY

text: great about America. I just thought we had
label: BODY

text: to change the way Washington worked.
label: BODY

text: Just go back in your mind to that period
label: BODY

text: and that long period where the other party
label: BODY

text: spent 12 years telling us how terrible the
label: BODY

text: Government was, and a lot of our guys were
label: BODY

text: sort of fighting a rearguard action defending
label: BODY

text: it. But most of the ideological battles which
label: BODY

text: took place in Washington were about yester-
label: BODY

text: day instead of about tomorrow. And so I set
label: BODY

text: off on this crazy journey with a lot of you,
label: BODY

text: based on a few simple ideas.
label: BODY

text: First of all, I asked myself, what is the
label: BODY

text: problem? The problem is that we have not
label: BODY

text: thought about how to take full advantage of
label: BODY

text: this explosion in technology and the
label: BODY

text: globalization of the economy in society and
label: BODY

text: at the same time figure out how not to leave
label: BODY

text: anybody behind and make our families and
label: BODY

text: our communities stronger and maintain our
label: BODY

text: push for peace and prosperity around the
label: BODY

text: world. We haven’t thought about how to
label: BODY

text: make the transition in a way that not only
label: BODY

text: provides vast opportunities for people like
label: BODY

text: those of us in this beautiful setting tonight,
label: BODY

text: but makes America as a nation stronger.
label: BODY

text: And it seemed to me that what we had
label: BODY

text: to do is to go back to some very basic things:
label: BODY

text: that we had an obligation to try to have op-
label: BODY

text: portunity for every person who was respon-
label: BODY

text: sible enough to deserve it; that we had to
label: BODY

text: try to build a community made up of every
label: BODY

text: law-abiding citizen without regard to what
label: BODY

text: other differences they had; that we had to
label: BODY

text: commit ourselves to be more involved in the
label: BODY

text: rest of the world, not less involved, because
label: BODY

text: the world is growing smaller and smaller; and
label: BODY

text: that we needed a different sort of Govern-
label: BODY

text: ment that could be much smaller—and it is
label: BODY

text: today, by the way. It’s the same size it was
label: BODY

text: in 1962—that’s the size of your Federal Gov-
label: BODY

text: ernment today. And I’m proud of that.
label: BODY

text: But what you need to know, we made it
label: BODY

text: smaller but more active, focused not so much
label: BODY

text: on telling people what to do or maintaining
label: BODY

text: old bureaucracies but giving people the tools
label: BODY

text: they need to make the most of their own
label: BODY

text: lives. Those were my ideas: opportunity, re-
label: BODY

text: sponsibility, community, a Government that
label: BODY

text: gives people the tools to make the most of
label: BODY

text: their own lives.
label: BODY

text: And I thought to myself, there are a whole
label: BODY

text: lot of things people believe that I don’t think
label: BODY

text: are true. I believed if we work at it, we could
label: BODY

text: reduce the deficit and still increase our
label: BODY

text: spending in education and health care if we
label: BODY

text: did it right. Well, 6 years later, we’ve got a
label: BODY

text: huge surplus, and we’ve nearly doubled
label: BODY

text: spending in education and health care.
label: BODY

text: I believed we could improve the economy
label: BODY

text: and improve the environment. The air is
label: BODY

text: cleaner and the water is cleaner than it was
label: BODY

text: 6 years ago. We’ve reduced chemicals in the
label: BODY

text: atmosphere from chemical plant emissions
label: BODY

text: by 90 percent in the last 6 years.
label: BODY

text: I believed that we could help people suc-
label: BODY

text: ceed at work and at home. And I still think
label: BODY

text: that’s one of the biggest problems we’ve got
label: BODY

text: May 7 / Administration of William J. Clinton, 1999
label: BODY

text: in this country, people trying to be good par-
label: BODY

text: ents and trying to meet their obligations at
label: BODY

text: work at the same time.
label: BODY

text: I believed that we could promote
label: BODY

text: entrepreneurialism and trade around the
label: BODY

text: world and still help people who, because of
label: BODY

text: their education or where they live, are at risk
label: BODY

text: of being left behind. Those are the things
label: BODY

text: that I believed.
label: BODY

text: I believed that we can be a force for peace
label: BODY

text: and recognize that there are some times
label: BODY

text: when we have to use our overwhelming mili-
label: BODY

text: tary force.
label: BODY

text: I believed that in welfare we could reduce
label: BODY

text: the welfare rolls, get more people to work,
label: BODY

text: and at the same time help people who were
label: BODY

text: on welfare to do a better job of raising their
label: BODY

text: children. That we didn’t have to hurt people
label: BODY

text: in their responsibilities as parents, to say if
label: BODY

text: you’re able-bodied you ought to work if you
label: BODY

text: can.
label: BODY

text: I didn’t believe that—all those choices and
label: BODY

text: all those debates that I kept hearing in Wash-
label: BODY

text: ington. And so we set out to do it, and the
label: BODY

text: public responded, and the people gave me
label: BODY

text: a chance to serve. And then in ’96, another
label: BODY

text: chance. And then in ’96 and ’98 kept return-
label: BODY

text: ing more of our people to the Congress so
label: BODY

text: that we’re at the point where we can almost
label: BODY

text: reverse the election of ’94. I think the elec-
label: BODY

text: tion in ’94 happened, by the way, because
label: BODY

text: we made the tough decisions as a party, all
label: BODY

text: alone, to reduce the deficit, without a single
label: BODY

text: vote from the other party, and increase our
label: BODY

text: investment in education. We made the tough
label: BODY

text: decision almost all alone to pass a crime bill
label: BODY

text: that put 100,000 police on the street, banned
label: BODY

text: assault weapons, and required the Brady
label: BODY

text: bill’s waiting period. And by the election in
label: BODY

text: ’94—and we tried to provide more health in-
label: BODY

text: surance, all alone, and didn’t have enough
label: BODY

text: votes to do it. And by ’94 what happened
label: BODY

text: was people knew what we’d done on the eco-
label: BODY

text: nomic plan, but they didn’t feel the economy
label: BODY

text: was getting better; they knew what we’d done
label: BODY

text: on the crime bill, but the NRA convinced
label: BODY

text: a bunch of hunters we were going to take
label: BODY

text: their rifles. By ’96 everybody still had their
label: BODY

text: rifles and the crime rate had gone down, the
label: BODY

text: economy had gone up, and we got reelected.
label: BODY

text: And the Congress is doing better ever since
label: BODY

text: our elections.
label: BODY

text: So now we’re poised for this election in
label: BODY

text: 2000. And what I want to say to you is, I
label: BODY

text: appreciate what Roy said about me, and it’s
label: BODY

text: nice to be introduced by your old friends.
label: BODY

text: They’ll lie about you a little now and then.
label: BODY

text: But the truth is, you must believe this, this
label: BODY

text: administration has succeeded because we
label: BODY

text: had the right ideas and the right approach
label: BODY

text: and we’re grounded in the right values, and
label: BODY

text: it’s what represents the heart and soul of the
label: BODY

text: Democratic Party today. And that’s why I’m
label: BODY

text: here.
label: BODY

text: We’ve got a lot of big decisions to make.
label: BODY

text: And you have to decide who is going to make
label: BODY

text: them. We have to deal with the aging crisis—
label: BODY

text: twice as many people over 65 by 2030. I hope
label: BODY

text: to live to be one of them. [Laughter] I’ve
label: BODY

text: given the Congress a plan that will save Social
label: BODY

text: Security, save Medicare, provide help for
label: BODY

text: people taking care of their parents and long-
label: BODY

text: term care, allow middle income people and
label: BODY

text: lower income people to save for their own
label: BODY

text: retirement for the first time and do it in a
label: BODY

text: way that pays down the national debt by 2015
label: BODY

text: to the lowest point it has been since before
label: BODY

text: World War I. And that’s really important to
label: BODY

text: keep the economy going, because we’ll be
label: BODY

text: less dependent on the vagaries of the global
label: BODY

text: financial system.
label: BODY

text: I’ve given the Congress a plan that will
label: BODY

text: improve the quality of education by ending
label: BODY

text: social promotion, by providing after-school
label: BODY

text: and summer school programs for our kids,
label: BODY

text: by finishing the work of hooking all our class-
label: BODY

text: rooms up to the Internet, by modernizing a
label: BODY

text: lot of these old school buildings and helping
label: BODY

text: the school districts that are having kids in
label: BODY

text: house trailers, by supporting better teaching,
label: BODY

text: and by having national academic standards,
label: BODY

text: which I hope our whole party will embrace
label: BODY

text: and help us in this great battle we’re in, be-
label: BODY

text: cause I think you should have local control
label: BODY

text: of the school about how to implement na-
label: BODY

text: tional academic standards.
label: BODY

text: There’s an international standard that all
label: BODY

text: of our children need to meet if we want them
label: BODY

text: to make a good living. And we’re about the
label: BODY

text: only advanced country in the world that
label: BODY

text: doesn’t have that. As a result, we’ve got the
label: BODY

text: finest system of higher education in the
label: BODY

text: world; no one believes that our system of ele-
label: BODY

text: mentary and secondary education is uni-
label: BODY

text: formly the finest in the world. And yet, it
label: BODY

text: Administration of William J. Clinton, 1999 / May 7
label: BODY

text: can be. And all the diversity we have in our
label: BODY

text: schools is a great asset in a global society,
label: BODY

text: but every one of those kids deserves a chance
label: BODY

text: at the brass ring.
label: BODY

text: I was in the Alexandria school system the
label: BODY

text: other day, across the river from the Capitol
label: BODY

text: and the White House. There are kids from
label: BODY

text: a hundred different racial and ethnic groups
label: BODY

text: there, nearly a hundred different native lan-
label: BODY

text: guages. Every one of them can make a con-
label: BODY

text: tribution to America if he or she gets a world-
label: BODY

text: class education. And to pretend that it ought
label: BODY

text: to be a local option whether they get it is,
label: BODY

text: I think, obscuring what is plainly real here.
label: BODY

text: So we Democrats stand for more flexibility
label: BODY

text: about how to do things, but for national
label: BODY

text: standards of excellence based on inter-
label: BODY

text: national standards of what our children need
label: BODY

text: to know. And I think the American people
label: BODY

text: are with us on that.
label: BODY

text: I could talk about a lot of other issues.
label: BODY

text: I’d just like to mention one or two more.
label: BODY

text: The Vice President is coming down here to
label: BODY

text: south Texas in a couple of weeks to our an-
label: BODY

text: nual empowerment zone conference. Since
label: BODY

text: 1993, we’ve been trying to figure out ways
label: BODY

text: to get more investment into poor urban
label: BODY

text: neighborhoods and poor rural areas and poor
label: BODY

text: Native American reservations, because there
label: BODY

text: are still a lot of people that haven’t partici-
label: BODY

text: pated in this economic recovery.
label: BODY

text: And I worry a lot about how we’re going
label: BODY

text: to keep America’s growth going and our un-
label: BODY

text: employment low without any inflation, espe-
label: BODY

text: cially if we have trouble overseas. One way
label: BODY

text: is to make more markets here at home. And
label: BODY

text: there are lots of places right here in Texas
label: BODY

text: where unemployment is still too high, too
label: BODY

text: many hardworking people still don’t have the
label: BODY

text: skills they need, and where if we could attract
label: BODY

text: the right investment in the right way we
label: BODY

text: could have dramatic growth. So this is going
label: BODY

text: to be a big challenge. If we can’t get around
label: BODY

text: now to giving poor rural areas and urban
label: BODY

text: areas that have been left behind the chances
label: BODY

text: they need, we’ll never get around to it.
label: BODY

text: Let me just mention one or two other
label: BODY

text: things. I am very interested in this whole
label: BODY

text: issue of balancing work and family. And I
label: BODY

text: think there’s some things we ought to do.
label: BODY

text: I think we ought to raise the minimum wage
label: BODY

text: again. I think we ought to strengthen the
label: BODY

text: family and medical leave law. I think we
label: BODY

text: ought to pass the Patients’ Bill of Rights. I
label: BODY

text: think we ought to pass our child care plan
label: BODY

text: to help lower income people with their child
label: BODY

text: care costs. We have to realize that most par-
label: BODY

text: ents have to work and every parent ought
label: BODY

text: to have the option to do it, but no parent
label: BODY

text: should have to sacrifice the most important
label: BODY

text: job any woman or man has, which is to raise
label: BODY

text: strong, good kids. There are a lot of things
label: BODY

text: out there we have to do. We’ve got a big
label: BODY

text: job to do in the world. You can see it today
label: BODY

text: with some of the problems we have.
label: BODY

text: Now, I’d like to close by just asking you
label: BODY

text: to think about three things and giving you
label: BODY

text: examples of what my philosophy is, that I
label: BODY

text: think is our party’s philosophy. These are the
label: BODY

text: best of times for Americans, but we’re all
label: BODY

text: pretty sobered up right now because of three
label: BODY

text: events of the recent days: One, are the ter-
label: BODY

text: rible tornadoes in Oklahoma and Kansas and,
label: BODY

text: to a lesser extent but still sad, in Texas and
label: BODY

text: Tennessee; two, is the heartbreaking incident
label: BODY

text: in Littleton, Colorado; and third, is the con-
label: BODY

text: tinuing conflict in Kosovo. Now, let me tell
label: BODY

text: you what they mean to me.
label: BODY

text: First, the tornadoes mean that none of us
label: BODY

text: should get too big for our britches. We’re
label: BODY

text: not in control. We have to maintain a certain
label: BODY

text: humility when thinking about all the prob-
label: BODY

text: lems of the world. But as our hearts go out
label: BODY

text: to those people—I’m going up to Oklahoma
label: BODY

text: City tomorrow to tour the damage and talk
label: BODY

text: about what we can do to help them put their
label: BODY

text: lives back together—I’m thinking about what
label: BODY

text: we can do to try to prepare better for the
label: BODY

text: next one. I’m thinking about what we can
label: BODY

text: do if we know we’re going to grow and ex-
label: BODY

text: pand in areas that have been tornado alleys,
label: BODY

text: what we ought to do to build houses that
label: BODY

text: will do a better job of withstanding them or
label: BODY

text: have quicker escapes to places that will be
label: BODY

text: safer. In other words, I think what we always
label: BODY

text: should be thinking about is: How can we
label: BODY

text: make it better? How can we deal with what
label: BODY

text: is going to come?
label: BODY

text: In the case of Littleton, on Monday, Hil-
label: BODY

text: lary and I and Al and Tipper Gore are going
label: BODY

text: to sponsor a big meeting at the White House
label: BODY

text: with people from the entertainment and
label: BODY

text: Internet communities, people from the gun
label: BODY

text: manufacturers, people from the religious
label: BODY

text: communities, people who work in schools on
label: BODY

text: problems of violence, students, a lot of other
label: BODY

text: May 7 / Administration of William J. Clinton, 1999
label: BODY

text: segments of our society, coming together to
label: BODY

text: talk about how we can start a national cam-
label: BODY

text: paign to reduce the likelihood of violence
label: BODY

text: against our children.
label: BODY

text: Now, I think it is important that you know
label: BODY

text: how I look at this. I think the world’s worst
label: BODY

text: thing we can do is to use this awful heart-
label: BODY

text: break to get into a fingerpointing session. Be-
label: BODY

text: cause the truth is that not a single soul here
label: BODY

text: knows exactly what triggered those kids. And
label: BODY

text: we all know that in any given time there will
label: BODY

text: be people who are more vulnerable than oth-
label: BODY

text: ers to whatever influences to which they’re
label: BODY

text: exposed to. But I do think we would all
label: BODY

text: admit, if we sort of take our defenses down,
label: BODY

text: that the society in which our children grow
label: BODY

text: up today, number one, throws things at them
label: BODY

text: faster; number two, gives them even more
label: BODY

text: opportunities to be isolated from their par-
label: BODY

text: ents and from their peers; number three, ex-
label: BODY

text: poses them at an earlier age and in greater
label: BODY

text: volume and intensity to more violence and
label: BODY

text: the coarsening of human relationships; and
label: BODY

text: number four, it’s way too easy for them get
label: BODY

text: things like Tech-9 assault pistols. And I think
label: BODY

text: we can all sort of admit that.
label: BODY

text: And what I’m trying to do is to figure out
label: BODY

text: what we should all do here to launch a genu-
label: BODY

text: ine grassroots national campaign where I try
label: BODY

text: to pass the laws I should pass; the gun manu-
label: BODY

text: facturers come forward and do what they
label: BODY

text: ought to do to try to protect our kids; the
label: BODY

text: entertainment community makes a contribu-
label: BODY

text: tion; the Internet community makes a con-
label: BODY

text: tribution—they’ve worked hard, by the way,
label: BODY

text: with the Vice President to try to give parents
label: BODY

text: more screening technologies—and the reli-
label: BODY

text: gious community comes forward; the mental
label: BODY

text: health community comes forward; the
label: BODY

text: schools provide more adequate counseling
label: BODY

text: services and peer mediation for the kids, and
label: BODY

text: what some of our schools are doing now, pro-
label: BODY

text: viding a hotline so kids who know what’s
label: BODY

text: going on in the school can call and tell some-
label: BODY

text: body without being subject to abuse.
label: BODY

text: There are lots of things to be done here.
label: BODY

text: But there’s also something to be said here
label: BODY

text: for recognizing the incredible pressures that
label: BODY

text: parents and children are under because life
label: BODY

text: is so fast and so crowded. And it is easy for
label: BODY

text: all of us, if we’re not careful, to wind up being
label: BODY

text: strangers in our own homes. And our chil-
label: BODY

text: dren need to understand also that no matter
label: BODY

text: how solid and rooted they are, childhood is
label: BODY

text: a fragile and difficult time. Every school will
label: BODY

text: always have its cliques. Every school will al-
label: BODY

text: ways have its groups. But we’ve got to teach
label: BODY

text: our kids that they can enjoy being in their
label: BODY

text: crowd without looking down on the others;
label: BODY

text: because people who are constantly subject
label: BODY

text: to ridicule and abuse are going to have their
label: BODY

text: lives twisted or distorted in some ways, unless
label: BODY

text: they are really superhuman.
label: BODY

text: So I’m looking forward to this. And all the
label: BODY

text: cynics who say it can’t be done, I would re-
label: BODY

text: mind you that teen pregnancy is now down
label: BODY

text: 5 years in a row because of a national grass-
label: BODY

text: roots movement, not because of any law we
label: BODY

text: passed in Washington. Drunk driving is down
label: BODY

text: because of Mothers and Students Against
label: BODY

text: Drunk Driving. We now have 10,000 compa-
label: BODY

text: nies that have voluntarily joined an alliance
label: BODY

text: that we organized a couple years ago to hire
label: BODY

text: people from welfare to work, and they’ve
label: BODY

text: hired over 400,000 people without a single
label: BODY

text: law being passed. We can do this. And I be-
label: BODY

text: lieve we can do it, but only if our political,
label: BODY

text: public life brings us together and not drives
label: BODY

text: us apart.
label: BODY

text: And the last thing I’d like to say is about
label: BODY

text: Kosovo. I know this is a difficult issue. I saw
label: BODY

text: the people with their signs on the way in,
label: BODY

text: saying we ought to end the fighting. Nobody
label: BODY

text: wants to do it more than me. I think those
label: BODY

text: of you who’ve known me for 30 years know
label: BODY

text: that the most difficult thing that I ever have
label: BODY

text: to do is use a superior position to put pres-
label: BODY

text: sure on somebody else, particularly if it in-
label: BODY

text: volves the use of violence. I’m not that sort
label: BODY

text: of person.
label: BODY

text: But let me tell you, since the end of com-
label: BODY

text: munism, we have seen the inevitable rise of
label: BODY

text: national aspirations and ethnic aspirations,
label: BODY

text: especially in Central and Eastern Europe. In
label: BODY

text: one place only, the former Yugoslavia, we
label: BODY

text: have seen that turned into a credo that says
label: BODY

text: it is all right to burn the homes, destroy the
label: BODY

text: records, destroy the churches—the mosques,
label: BODY

text: in this case—and the museums, and the li-
label: BODY

text: braries, and the very lives of families; it’s all
label: BODY

text: right to rape the daughters; it’s all right to
label: BODY

text: shoot the sons; it’s all right to do this.
label: BODY

text: And for 3 years, we worked, through the
label: BODY

text: United Nations and negotiations and every-
label: BODY

text: thing else, to end the war in Bosnia. And
label: BODY

text: finally, we ended the war in Bosnia when
label: BODY

text: Administration of William J. Clinton, 1999 / May 8
label: BODY

text: NATO bombed and when the opposition
label: BODY

text: forces started winning some battles on the
label: BODY

text: ground. And we’ve been able to maintain a
label: BODY

text: peace there.
label: BODY

text: People don’t have to like each other. Peo-
label: BODY

text: ple may have legitimate grievances. But eth-
label: BODY

text: nic cleansing and killing people wholesale be-
label: BODY

text: cause of their race or religion is wrong. And
label: BODY

text: the United States is in a position to stand
label: BODY

text: against it, and we ought to.
label: BODY

text: I know there are a lot of people who dis-
label: BODY

text: agree with me. They say, ‘‘Well, we don’t
label: BODY

text: have any vital national interest.’’ I would
label: BODY

text: argue to you that we do. It’s not only a moral,
label: BODY

text: humanitarian issue. We’ll be better off if our
label: BODY

text: best allies in the world, in Europe, live in
label: BODY

text: a continent that is whole and democratic and
label: BODY

text: at peace and free of this sort of thing.
label: BODY

text: First of all, they won’t be wasting their
label: BODY

text: money tearing each other up. Secondly,
label: BODY

text: they’ll be better trading partners. Thirdly,
label: BODY

text: they’ll be better partners in helping us solve
label: BODY

text: problems in other parts of the world. And
label: BODY

text: if we can put an end to ethnic cleansing in
label: BODY

text: Europe, then we can put an end to it in Afri-
label: BODY

text: ca, and we can put an end to it wherever
label: BODY

text: else it rears its ugly head.
label: BODY

text: If we can’t solve this problem, it’s very dif-
label: BODY

text: ficult to understand how our children are
label: BODY

text: going to live in peace in a world where every
label: BODY

text: radical terrorist group can get on the Internet
label: BODY

text: and figure out how to build a bomb or get
label: BODY

text: weapons or do anything else they want to
label: BODY

text: do. We have got, at least, to tell people that
label: BODY

text: in the world of the 21st century, it is not
label: BODY

text: okay to kill people just because they’re of
label: BODY

text: a different race or ethnicity or religion.
label: BODY

text: That’s why I must say, I want to applaud
label: BODY

text: the Senators who are here, who are trying
label: BODY

text: to pass that hate crimes act in the legislature,
label: BODY

text: in honor of James Byrd. I think it’s very im-
label: BODY

text: portant. It makes a statement.
label: BODY

text: This is the last thing I’ll say about this.
label: BODY

text: I’ve already talked longer than I meant to,
label: BODY

text: but if you don’t remember anything else I
label: BODY

text: say, remember this: It is one thing to say that
label: BODY

text: we all ought to get along together and quite
label: BODY

text: another to do what is necessary for us to do
label: BODY

text: so in decency and honor.
label: BODY

text: The differences among us are a part of
label: BODY

text: what makes life more interesting and makes
label: BODY

text: this country so successful, as long as they are
label: BODY

text: contained. When the differences among us
label: BODY

text: are used, as they are in Kosovo today, as they
label: BODY

text: were in Bosnia before, as an instrument of
label: BODY

text: human destruction, they can quickly make
label: BODY

text: life unbearable.
label: BODY

text: Now, we can’t force anybody to like any-
label: BODY

text: body else. Maybe not everybody in this place
label: BODY

text: tonight likes everybody else. But we live ac-
label: BODY

text: cording to certain rules, and we do it not
label: BODY

text: only because it is morally right but because
label: BODY

text: we do better when other people do well.
label: BODY

text: When we do the right thing or, as Hillary
label: BODY

text: says, when we act like we’re in a village, we
label: BODY

text: all are better off.
label: BODY

text: So I ask you to think about this. The
label: BODY

text: Democratic Party has stood for community
label: BODY

text: and for opportunity and for citizen respon-
label: BODY

text: sibility. We have refused to accept all these
label: BODY

text: phony choices we were presented with, be-
label: BODY

text: tween economic growth and the environ-
label: BODY

text: ment, between accountability and help in
label: BODY

text: education, and all the other things. These
label: BODY

text: ideas have led America to a better place.
label: BODY

text: That’s why I’m here. I’m glad I was Presi-
label: BODY

text: dent. I hope I was the instrument of a lot
label: BODY

text: of the good things that have happened in this
label: BODY

text: country. But the most important thing is that
label: BODY

text: we continue in this direction, that we stay
label: BODY

text: on this course, that we embrace these ideas.
label: BODY

text: And that is why it is important to support
label: BODY

text: this party.
label: BODY

text: I’m very grateful to you. Thank you, and
label: BODY

text: God bless you.
label: BODY

text: NOTE: The President spoke at 8:38 p.m. at a pri-
label: BODY

text: vate residence. In his remarks, he referred to Roy
label: BODY

text: and Mary Spence, dinner hosts; Texas State Sen-
label: BODY

text: ators Carlos Truan and Gonzalo Barrientos; Gary
label: BODY

text: Mauro, former Texas land commissioner; Judy
label: BODY

text: Trabulsi, Nancy Williams, and Tom Henderson,
label: BODY

text: who worked with the President on the 1972
label: BODY

text: McGovern campaign in Texas; former Gov. Ann
label: BODY

text: Richards of Texas; and Joseph J. Andrew, national
label: BODY

text: chair, Democratic National Committee. This item
label: BODY

text: was not received in time for publication in the
label: BODY

text: appropriate issue.
label: BODY

text: The President’s Radio Address
label: HH2

text: Good morning. I want to talk to you today
label: BODY

text: about our efforts to help the people and com-
label: BODY

text: munities devastated by the terrible tornadoes
label: BODY

text: that hit Oklahoma, Kansas, Texas, and Ten-
label: BODY

text: nessee this week. These tornadoes killed over
label: BODY

text: 50 people, injured hundreds more, and dam-
label: BODY

text: aged or destroyed thousands of homes and
label: BODY
